topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Raaz Herzberg and Wiz’s extraordinary growth, plus what the episode will cover (early pivots, marketing lessons, leadership, and more).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS and Rippling.

topics.title: Early idea confusion and pivot signals
topics.summary: Raaz describes the initial Beyond Networks concept, intense customer-call cadence during early COVID, and the key signal: polite interest without real understanding or pull—leading to a pivot toward cloud security.

topics.title: What real customer pull looks like
topics.summary: They contrast vague positive feedback with true buying intent: pricing questions, POV requests, and internal introductions—plus the bias founders have toward affirmation over uncomfortable truth.

topics.title: Saying 'I don’t understand' and culture
topics.summary: Raaz recounts raising confusion about what they were building, how that vulnerability unlocked clarity, and why a flat, psychologically safe culture makes it possible to surface critical issues early.

topics.title: Post-pivot momentum and early POV execution
topics.summary: After the cloud-security pivot, customer urgency becomes obvious; Raaz shares a lesson from a Fortune 10 POV: don’t over-push—use friction to confirm commitment and ensure mutual pull.

topics.title: Founders selling before hiring sales
topics.summary: Raaz explains how Wiz closed early deals without a sales team, why doing the full loop yourself builds confidence and learning, and why hiring someone rarely fixes something you can’t do end-to-end.

topics.title: Why Raaz moved from product to CMO
topics.summary: Raaz shares how Wiz’s scaling bottleneck shifted to awareness and brand, prompting the CEO to ask her to lead marketing—despite her having to learn core marketing concepts from scratch.

topics.title: Following the heat: bottlenecks shift by stage
topics.summary: Raaz explains her “heat” metaphor: early heat in product discovery, then engineering, then sales, then marketing—guiding where leadership attention and top talent should focus as the company grows.

topics.title: Board meeting story and nontraditional marketing approach
topics.summary: Raaz describes her first board meeting as CMO, leaning on deep product/customer knowledge over “traditional” marketing playbooks, and focusing on fast awareness gains by making noise.

topics.title: Why CMOs fail: trust, domain, and role breadth
topics.summary: Raaz outlines why the CMO role is uniquely hard: high visibility, fragile founder trust, need for deep domain/product understanding, and managing disparate functions (performance, brand, events, field).

topics.title: Creating noise: RSA themed booth and brand shift
topics.summary: Raaz contrasts product vs marketing iteration costs, then shares bold awareness tactics like a Wizard-of-Oz RSA booth and a bright, optimistic brand identity to stand out in a dark cybersecurity category.

topics.title: Being willing to fail and learning from friction
topics.summary: Raaz explains her comfort with likely failure as a driver of career moves and experimentation, tracing it to childhood lessons about seeking friction, building courage, and investing where you’re weakest.

topics.title: What product leaders miss about marketing clarity
topics.summary: From a marketing lens, Raaz argues product teams underestimate marketing’s importance and the need for crisp, scalable messaging; ambiguity that works in 1:1 product conversations breaks at scale.
